title: How are novels and novellas differentiated? - Quora

response.answer_text: Here’s one estimate I found: Novel — over 40,000 words Novella — 17,500 to 40,000 words Novelette — 7,500 to 17,500 words Short story — under 7,500 words A nov·el = “a fictitious prose narrative of book length, typically representing character and action with some degree of realism”; a no·vel·la = “a short novel or long short story”. “Long” and “short” are, of course, relative terms, so my understanding is that, generally speaking, a novella is merely a tale that is too short to be legitimately labeled a novel. This varies considerably between adult’s books and children’s books.

For a novella, the word count range is somewhere from 17,000 words to 40,000 words. Novellas don't generally have more than 100 pages, but that can differ depending on font and stuff. For a novel, the range is generally 40,000 to 100,000 (the upper limit might be more depending on the genre). But this range isn't fixed, and depends on the genre and the publishing houses. For different genres, word count limit is different. Like for thriller it might be 100,000, but for romance it's somewhere 60,000 to 80,000. Even publishing houses have a set length for genres and formats, and accordingly books are selected and edited to match up with the limits. Hope this helps :)
